page.title: 12Sheep Farming in Lamberhurst
page.content: { Kent}or{Romney}are the traditional breeds, but cross-breeds are now favoured, promoting better growth and carcusses. The{ewes}usually have their{lambs} in March. They are turned out to grass until after 16 to 20 weeks the lambs are ready for slaughter. The ewe's fleece is{sheared}in June and is worth Â£3. To prevent worms each lamb is drenched every 3 weeks and all are dipped twice against sheep scab. Lambs not ready for slaughter are weaned on to lush grass or fattened on a catch crop of rape, stubble or turnips. In October the{ram}runs with about 30 ewes for about 6 weeks. The ewes stay in the fields until Christmas when they are brought in and fed on silage or hay and concentrates until lambing.
